section: Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. ('CCGI') and Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc. ('PVSS'), (the 'Parties' or 'Joint Venturers' if referred to collectively, or the 'Entity' if referred to singularly), by this Agreement associate themselves as business associates, and not as partners, in the formation of a joint venture (the 'Joint Venture'), for the purpose of engaging generally in the business provided for by terms and provisions of this Agreement.
explanation: The initial clause attempts to define the relationship as a joint venture but states they are associating as 'business associates, and not as partners.' This is ambiguous because joint ventures are often considered partnerships under the law. The attempt to distinguish it from a partnership may be legally problematic, as the actual operation of the venture will determine its legal classification regardless of this clause. The use of the term 'Entity' to refer to the 'Parties' if referred to singularly' is structurally flawed and not understandable.

section: Except as agreed upon by mutual consent, the Joint Venturers shall not be required to make any capital contribution to the Joint Venture.
explanation: This clause is an omission that undermines the purpose of a joint venture. Typically, joint ventures involve some form of capital contribution, whether monetary, in-kind services, or assets. By stating that no capital contribution is required unless mutually agreed upon, the agreement lacks a fundamental component which can lead to structural flaws. This lack of clarity about initial resources causes practical and potentially legal issues. It also fails to detail what happens if capital is needed but not contributed, which could be essential for operating the joint venture successfully.

section: The Joint Venturers recognize that both of the Joint Venturers are and will continue to be engaged in the conduct of their respective businesses for their own account. Neither Participant shall be entitled to compensation for services rendered to the Joint Venture as such, but each Investor shall be reimbursed for all direct expenses, including travel, office, and all other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in the operation of the affairs of the Joint Venture and the promotion of its businesses. It is agreed that either Joint Venturer shall, except as provided for below, have authority to execute instruments of any character relating to the affairs of the Joint Venture; provided, that without the written consent or approval of both of the Joint Venturers: (i) the Joint Venture shall incur no liability of any sort, nor any indebtedness for borrowed funds; (ii) no assets owned in the name of the Joint Venture be disposed of; and (iii) no commitment to purchase any item for the Joint Venture shall be made.
explanation: The clause concerning the Joint Venturers continuing their own businesses and not receiving compensation for services to the Joint Venture is contradictory. While it is standard for joint ventures to allow partners to have separate businesses, preventing compensation for JV services introduces a structural flaw. Requiring unanimous consent for incurring liability, disposing of assets, or purchasing items severely restricts operational flexibility and conflicts with the stated intent of granting each Joint Venturer authority. The use of the word 'Investor' in the second sentence is misaligned, as the agreement calls them 'Joint Venturers'.
